ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

CITY COUNCIL SERVICES TO PALMER ROAD AREA


    1. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister whether he will make a Statement as to the availability of City Council services to the residents of the Palmer Road area.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Sir, a survey of the kampong at Palmer Road was carried out some months ago. It showed that a good number of the dwellings were unauthorised sheds constructed from packing cases and other inflammable material or in a ruinous condition. The Fire Department considered it dangerous in these circumstances to allow electric lines to this kampong from the City Council mains.

    With regard to water, there are three existing standpipes in the area. A fourth standpipe has been approved by the Urban and Rural Services Council but it cannot yet be installed as the private landowner is strongly resisting its erection over his land.

    Sir, the aim is to offer these people decent low-cost accommodation now being built by the Housing Board. By the middle of next year, there should be enough $20 flats available to house all those now on the register; and with the housing programme maintaining its present momentum, there is every hope that there will be low-cost flats available for all by the end of next year for those who are now living in sub-standard tenements and huts.

    Mr David Marshall: I am pleased to hear the information given by the Prime Min ister. Perhaps he is aware that there are approximately 3,000 people living in this particular area. Could no temporary measures be taken to supply

Column: 5

them with electricity and particularly with water if necessary to acquire the piece of land necessary for the erection of that standpipe?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, on the first point regarding the supply of electricity, the Urban and Rural Service Council have to take the advice of the Fire Department. But as for the standpipe, I can assure the Member for Anson that we are contemplating such action to erect the standpipe despite the landowner's wishes.

WATER CONSUMPTION


    2. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister what is the extent of the average daily consumption in 1961 of water received from the catchment area occupied by the Royal Singapore Golf Club, and the average total daily consumption of water in Singapore in 1960-1961.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, the average yield from the MacRitchie Catchment area of 1,890 acres, out of which about 268 acres are occupied by the Royal Singapore Golf Club, was 4,331 million gallons per day or 1,580 million gallons per annum in 1961.

    The average daily consumption of water in Singapore was about 67 million gallons per day for 1960-1961.

    Mr David Marshall: In the light of the figures given and the negligible quantity of water referable to the 268 acres occupied by the Royal Singapore Golf Club, could the Prime Minister indicate whether he has any plans in mind for more appropriate utilisation of that area for the public benefit?

    The Prime Minister: May I inform the Member for Anson that on these matters I have to take the advice of the Water Engineer, and his advice in connection with the forestation of the catchment area was that no further trees should be allowed to be struck down in this catchment area. It may be of interest to the Member for Anson that I turned down a request by another club to extend their golf course, as that would imply more trees coming down.

Column: 6

Therefore, I am unable to take what I would consider the hazardous step of allowing any more trees in the catchment area to be struck down.

    4.3 million gallons per day is not a negligible amount of water, for which we should be grateful and certainly were grateful last year at the time of the drought.

    Mr David Marshall: I understand from the Prime Minister that 4.3 million gallons was from 1,890 acres. Of that, only 268 acres are occupied by the Royal Singa pore Golf Club, which is about one-seventh. So the 4.3 million gallons is not attributable to the Royal Singapore Golf Club. I would enquire from the Prime Minister whether, apart from any planning for the purpose of utilisation of that area to create a satellite town, he would consider transforming it into a public park?

    Mr Speaker: It is an entirely different question.

    The Prime Minister: May I answer it?

    Mr Speaker: Yes, if the Prime Minister wishes to.

    The Prime Minister: Surely if there is demand for using the land as a public park, I will not have the slightest hesitation in utilising the land as a public park. In fact, for the information of the Member for Anson, both golf courses are open to members of the public on all public holidays for their use as a place for picnicking and other uses not inconsistent with the desires of the Health Department with regard to rubbish and other sanitary conditions.

PRIME MINISTER'S VISIT TO LONDON
(Discussions with British Ministers)


    3. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister whether he will make a statement on his discussions with British Ministers on his recent trip to London.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, in London, in May, I had discussions with the United Kingdom Prime Minister, the Commonwealth and Colonial Secretaries

Column: 7

and the Minister of Defence on the arrangements to be made before merger for the transfer of responsibility for foreign affairs, defence and security to the Central Government of the new Federation on merger.

    I had a useful exchange of views on a number of these subjects. As the House was not then sitting on the day of my return - 3lst May - I held a Press conference at which I think all relevant points were raised and answered. If there are any specific matters on which the Member for Anson desires further explanation, I shall enlarge on them in this House.

    Mr David Marshall: Would the Prime Minister indicate whether there was any discussion as to the continuation of our bases for the utilisation of SEATO powers?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, I would refer the Member for Anson to the statement which was issued after the meeting of the Federation Prime Minister and the Minister for the United Kingdom at which the status of the base was sufficiently and lucidly explained. I was only interested in one particular aspect with regard to the base - namely, the question of redundancy. I had some discussions with the Minister of Defence on the possibilities of maintaining the civilian employment for some time at its present level, and later, should there be cause for redundancy, of ensuring that there are adequate redundancy terms.

    Mr David Marshall: Perhaps one more subject, if you will permit, Mr Speaker. Could the Prime Minister indicate whether any attempt was made to ask the United Kingdom Government to utilise its good offices in order to make more acceptable the proposed terms of our future relations with the Federation as contained in the Government's White Paper?

    The Prime Minister: Sir, as I have explained before, the attitude of my Government is that merger is a matter between the peoples and the Governments of Singapore and the Federation of Malaya. It has nothing to do with

Column: 8

the United Kingdom Government other than the fact that on merger they will have to transfer all responsibility for foreign affairs, defence and security to the Central Government of the new Federation. I would consider it not only improper but politically unprecedented to ask a colonial administration to try and intervene in what I consider to be a purely family matter within the Malayan nation.

RENEWAL OF NEGOTIATIONS ON
CLOSER RELATIONS WITH
FEDERATION AFTER PUBLICATION OF COBBOLD
COMMISSION REPORT


    4. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister whether Government will seek to renew negotiations on the proposed closer relations with the Federation after the Cobbold Commission Report has been published.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, until the Cobbold Commission Report is published, it is not possible to answer this question.

    Mr David Marshall: Am I to understand, Mr Speaker, that the Prime Minister is unaware of the contents of the Cobbold Commission Report?

    The Prime Minister: I think the Member for Anson can assume that until the Report is published, it will be inappropriate for anyone to indicate whether he does or does not know what is in the Report. But I would like to assure the hon. Member that, in my duty as the Prime Minister of Singapore, every stage in the development of the creation of Malaysia, which is gathering momentum month by month - almost week by week - is watched closed by my colleagues and myself in order to see that the interests of Singapore within this larger federation are properly safeguarded.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, I was not seeking information as to the contents of the Cobbold Commission Report. I seem to have been misunderstood. I was only enquiring whether, in the light of the knowledge that he has, he would be seeking renewal of negotiations in respect of the White Paper proposals?

Column: 9



    Mr Speaker: The answer has been given.

    The Prime Minister: May I reply?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    The Prime Minister: I think the Member for Anson is on this occasion wilfully slow on the uptake. I have not indicated whether I know or do not know the Cobbold Commission Report. It would be improper for me to indicate one way or the other. All I have indicated is that my colleagues and I, as persons entrusted with the interests of Singapore, are watching with considerable interest and painstaking care developments which are, as I have said, gathering momentum week by week. I can assure the Member for Anson - as I did assure the people of Singapore - that before the Federation of Malaysia takes place, all the necessary safeguards regarding equal rights for all of us shall be written into the Constitution.

LIGHTING IN BUSES


    5. Mr David Marshall asked the Deputy Prime Minister whether he will give details of the extent of lighting required to be provided for in buses with particular reference to the entrances to buses.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, the law requires that adequate artificial lighting shall be provided for the illumination of the interior of a bus at all times between sunset and sunrise when passengers are being carried.

    The number of lights in the interior of a bus varies according to the size of the bus. A large bus (overall length 30 ft.) has eight to ten lights, and a smaller bus (overall length 27 ft. 6 ins.) has six lights. The average spacing between these lights is four to seven feet, suitably distributed along the ceiling. The arrangement of the lights is such that invariably there are two lamps in close proximity to the entrance.

    Internal illumination is further augmented by the infiltration of light from illuminated rear number plate and destination box situated at the rear end of the ceiling. The lamps in the interior

Column: 10

of the bus normally have frosted glass covers and are usually 10" long 4" wide. Voltage is 24 and wattage 36.

    Some buses have one light and some have two on the steps at the entrances. These lights are usually small (3" x 1") and recessed. Voltage is 24 and wattage is from 3 to 5.

    Mr David Marshall: Is the Deputy Prime Minister aware that some bus companies, with an eye to economy, are in fact ignoring these regulations and cutting sometimes as much as half the required number of lights in their buses?

    Mr Speaker: The supplementary question being?

    Mr David Marshall: Is the Deputy Prime Minister aware?

    Mr Speaker: That is giving information.

    Mr David Marshall: Is he aware that such is the case?

    Mr Speaker: That is giving information.

    Mr David Marshall: And would he take steps?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, if the Member for Anson would patrol the streets of Singapore and take down the numbers of buses which, to his knowledge, are inadequately illuminated and inform the Registrar of Vehicles. I am quite sure action will be taken.

    Mr David Marshall: Am I to understand that the Registrar of Vehicles has no one to check on the adequacy or otherwise of compliance with these regulations that my assistance is sought?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Sir, although no doubt it is the function of the Registrar of Vehicles to see that the regulations are implemented, it has not come to his knowledge that buses are inadequately illuminated. This is the first complaint that I have received. This complaint comes from the Member for Anson, and if he can indicate which bus company is at fault, the Registrar of Vehicles will certainly look into the matter.

MALAY NAMES ON NEW
POSTAGE STAMPS


    6. Mr David Marshall asked the Deputy Prime Minister whether the Government would consider supplementing the Latin name with the Malay name of the design on the new postage stamps in future reprints.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, it was decided to use the scientific names instead of the Malay names on the postage stamps for the following reasons: -

    (a) The known Malayan names are regional in character and the fishes are known by different names in different parts of Malaya. For example, the fish which is depicted on the 25-cent stamp is known as sepat ronggeng in Penang and as sepat padi in Perak.

    (b) Even in the same area fishes are sometimes known by more than one local Malay name. For example, the fish on the 6-cent stamp is known as Sumpit and Blibiran in Singapore.

    (e) The same Malay name may sometimes be applied to different fishes. For example, the fish on the 20-cent stamp and the fish on the 6-cent stamp are both known as Sum pit.

    (d) The fish on the 4-cent stamp has no known Malay name.

    Until the Dewan Bahasa has standardised the nomenclature of flora and fauna, I believe the safest course in order to avoid controversy is to adopt their Latin scientific names, which are known by botanists and zoologists all over the world.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, these are Singapore stamps, not Penang nor Trengganu. The Government has not extended that far, Sir. In the light of that information, would the Deputy Prime Minister indicate whether he would consider utilising the Malay names where available of those fish which are current in Singapore?

Column: 12



    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Sir, we know that some types of fish do exist in Singapore and some types do not exist in Singapore. As I have said just now, for example, the fish on the 4-cent stamp has no known Malay name, and if the Member for Anson so desires, I do not mind calling the fish on the 4-cent stamp as Ikan Marshall!

AIRPORT TERMINAL BUILDING
(Date of Completion)


    7. Mr David Marshall asked the Deputy Prime Minister when it is expected that the permanent Terminal Building at Singapore Airport will be completed, and what interim provisions are being made for the comfort of transit passengers.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, The permanent Terminal Building at the Singapore Airport will be completed m the early part of 1964.

    Transit passengers at the Singapore Airport are being accommodated in the Airport Restaurant and the Reception Room. The present Terminal Building is a temporary one built in 1955 when the Member for Anson was Chief Minister. No transit lounge was provided for by the then Government in this building and therefore transit passengers have hitherto been accommodated in the Airport Restaurant. Various proposals to put up a temporary transit lounge have been studied by a Committee consisting of Airport officials and members representing the airline operators, but these proposals were considered either not feasible or uneconomic in view of the fact that a concrete plan to build a new Terminal Building is in hand.

    Mr David Marshall: I see, Mr Speaker, that I am responsible for this terminal building. But I would inquire whether it is not possible to improve the accommodation because the Deputy Prime Minister must be aware that the existing accommodation is acutely uncomfortable and in some cases shabby in the extreme. There must be some way of improving it without too great a cost during the intervening 18 months.

Column: 13



    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Sir, I have already given the answer to that question. I said that a Committee had looked into the matter in detail and it had come to the conclusion that it, is not worthwhile proceeding with.

COMMON MARKET
(Further Statement)


    9. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Finance whether he has any further statement to make as regards the proposed Common Market with the Federation of Malaya.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, a team of international experts is now being assembled to undertake the study and the Government hopes to be able to announce shortly the names of the team and the eminent international expert who will lead it. As I said before, these arrangements are being made by the Federation Government who have kept us continuously informed of progress. Any public statement will have to be timed with that of the Federation Government.

    In passing, I may say that the Common Market, which we all want, presupposes merger with the Federation. If by some unimaginable mischance, merger is thwarted through the machinations of the Communists and their stooges, then Singapore can say goodbye to the Common Market. The fact that this international mission will soon proceed with their work shows that there is confidence, not only in Singapore and the Federation, but also in the world outside that merger will before long be an accomplished fact.

    Mr David Marshall: I would ask the Minister for Finance whether he has forgotten that in 1959 in this House he promised the people of Singapore a Common Market in the near future without any reference to merger.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker. Sir, the European Common Market took morel than 15 years to be established. What the Member for Anson says just underlines my emphasis on the connection between Common Market and merger. In 1959, there was no

Column: 15

prospect of merger, and consequently our discussions with the Federation got bogged down fairly soon. Now that merger is on the horizon, it becomes much easier to discuss these matters with the Federation Government. Therefore, if the Member for Anson is anxious to see a Common Market between Singapore and the Federation, then he must spend all his energies to bring about a speedy merger between the two territories.

UNCLAIMED BALANCES IN BANKS
(Possible Utilisation)


    10. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Finance whether he has any information as to the extent, and possible utilisaticn by subrogation, of customers' balances in banks unclaimed for more than seven years.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The present returns submitted by banks under the Banking Ordinance, 1962, do not indicate the number of dormant customers' accounts or the amount of unclaimed balances on such accounts which have not been operative for seven or more years.

    The banking legislation of Singapore and the Federation of Malaya does not specifically designate what disposition should be made of unclaimed deposits in banks. It is generally understood that these balances remain a liability of the bank until they are paid. In practice, the balances are transferred by the banks to an "Unclaimed Balances Account" and would appear together with other balances as liabilities on the bank's balance sheet.

    In the United States the Federal Reserve Act and the National Bank Act make no provisions with regard to disposal of unclaimed bank balances. The United States Supreme Court had ruled that a State should not dissolve the contracts of deposit even after 20 years and that national banks could not be required to pay to the State the amounts due.

Column: 16



    In Britain the question of unclaimed moneys in banks has been much discussed and exaggerated. A Bill entitled the Dormant Bank Balances and Unclaimed Securities Bill was referred by the British Parliament to a Select Committee which after considering it reported in December 1919 that a much longer period than six years should elapse before a state of dormancy, having legal consequences involving publicity, should be recognised. The majority opinion of the Select Committee was that an account should he deemed to be dormant only after it had not been operative for thirty years or more. The Select Committee also suggested that boxes and parcels entrusted to banks for safe keeping should be subject to legislative action for their disposal only after 70 years had elapsed. As a result of the recommendations of this Select Committee, the British Parliament took no action on the Bill.

    In India the practice is to require every banking company to submit within thirty days after the close of each calendar year a return of accounts which had not been operated upon for ten years or more. The return should give particulars of the deposits standing to the credit of each account but there would appear to be no provision for the disposal of any unclaimed assets.

    In Australia, however, there is specific legislation under the Banking Act of 1957 to provide for the disposal of "unclaimed monies" which are defined as all principals, interests, dividends, bonuses, profits and sums of money legally payable by a bank in respect of which the time for recovery had expired and includes money to the credit of an account which has not been operative either by deposit or withdrawal for a period of not less than seven years. The unclaimed monies will be paid by a bank to the Commonwealth and will be held in a Trust Fund for six years, after which it would be paid to the Consolidated Revenue Fund. If at any time a legitimate claim is established, such monies shall be paid to the bank and the bank shall thereupon pay the claimant.

Column: 17



    I give this account of some instance of international practice in this matter to show that there are wide variations in policy. So far as Singapore is concern ed, the banks are of the view that it is not a matter Of sufficient importance as to justify new legislation. I myself am inclined to leave it well alone, especially as experience and practice in other countries have not produced any unanimity in dealing with the matter.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, in the light of the recognised fact, how shall we say it, that the banks have no right to benefit by this unearned profit of unclaimed balances, would the Minister not consider advising the Government to introduce legislation analogous to the Australian legislation whereby the Government could at least utilise the money pending a claim? The use of the word "subrogation" in my original question was subrogation to rights and liabilities. There is no question of extinguishing a customer's right whether it is seven years or 15 years. But in the meanwhile the Government can use this money without interest. Will the Minister consider it? This is a Christmas present almost of fairly considerable sums which the Government could utilise, some of it permanently and some of it temporarily without interest.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: In the first instance, I do not think that the sums of money involved are considerable; and, secondly, in so far as other countries have considered this proposal, the majority view is not to fellow the Australian practice. It could be that such a majority view is based on ether ancient concepts of the right of private property. As I said, I myself do not think that we should, before other countries have followed the Australian example, introduce in this country a new principle which is not accepted and followed in the majority of countries with banking systems similar to ours.

TAX LEGISLATION ON MARRIED WOMEN'S INCOME


    11. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Finance whether he will consider introducing legislation to treat the income of married women from all

Column: 18

sources as being the income of single women for tax purposes.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The recent amendment to the Income Tax Ordinance to provide for separate assessment in respect of the earned income of a married woman was to adjust a longstanding inequality and to bring about a social betterment. But to extend this treatment to other sources of income would open new avenues for evading payment of tax. For one thing, a way is open for the manipulation of profits so that the husband's income can be transferred to that of his wife's so as to reduce the incidence of tax and bring about a loss to the revenue. This fact was recognised when the recent amendment was not extended to cover all kinds of professions and businesses. Moreover, an opportunity is created to bring wives into partnership which would lead to the avoidance of both income tax and estate duty. It will be appreciated that, in the absence of gift duty, which is a normal compensatory levy in place of the loss of income tax and estate duty, such loss of revenue could not be accepted.

    For these reasons, I do not consider the proposal of the hon. Member a good one.

    Mr David Marshall: Admitting the validity of that part of the objection raised by the Minister for Finance, Sir, would he rot recognise that, in fact, the reasons indicated are not applicable where a married woman had unearned income before marriage? She might have inherited property from which she was drawing income. Would he consider in that respect that there can be no question of evasion, making her unearned income prior to marriage taxable as a femme sole?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I can see one immediate objection to that, and that would be the possible transfer of property from the man to his fiancee. I think this matter is not so simple as it looks. As I said, if there is in force a tax on gifts inter-vivos, then possibly the inducement to avoid income tax by distribution of property would be much less.
